field_edited_text.value:
RoADWAY 147

With the exception of the Type “A” Cantilever Span, all structures are of
the deck type. The Type “A” Span is of the through type because of navi-
gation requirements.

The lengths and types of spans were largely determined by the criterion,
that the economical span length is a function of the cost of piers and cost
of steel in the superstructure. Full advantage was taken of any possible
duplication of spans and the resulting decreased cost of fabrication. The
economic possibilities of various schemes of erection were also studied.

Specifications

The designs on which this report is based were made in accordance with
the provisions of the Standard Specifications for Highway Bridges of the
American Association of State Highway Officials, dated 1935. This speci-
fication is widely used throughout the United States and is considered au-
thoritative, its requirements being in line with the most modern structural
practice. It is expected that the final designs will be in accordance with
this specification, modified slightly as may be found necessary because of
the unusual size and importance of the structure.

Lave Load

The bridge is designed to carry two lanes, (H-20 loading), each lane 12
feet wide. This loading is as specified by the American Association of State
Highway Officials and is believed ample for present and future conditions.

ROADWAY

The roadway for the Chesapeake Bay Bridge will be the same for either
the Millers Island-Tolchester Site or the Sandy Point-Kent Island Site
and will consist of an open mesh type flooring filled with concrete, which
when completed will present the appearance of a concrete roadway surface.
The weight of the floor in the design of the bridge includes an allowance
for the future addition of two inches of asphalt or other wearing surface.

The plans provide for dividing the roadway into two lanes by the construc-
tion of permanent roadway markers in the surface of the roadway slab.
The central marker will be a colored stripe obtained by the use of colored
aggregates laid monolithically with the other concrete to divide the bridge
into two lanes operating in opposite.directions. Colored stripes will also
be constructed immediately adjacent and parallel to the curbs.

The footways for this bridge have been designed 1 foot 6 inches wide
and are intended as emergency footways only, since little, if any, pedestrian
